cellularAutomata.util.music
Class MusicalScales

java.lang.Object
  cellularAutomata.util.music.MusicalScales

public class MusicalScales
extends java.lang.Object

Contains methods that convert the number of a note on a scale into a piano's key number. For example, in the C major scale, the scale number 0 would be a C, the scale number 1 would be a D, the scale number 2 would be an E, the scale number 3 would be an F, etc. The piano's keys are numbered from 0 to 87 with 39 as middle C. So in the C major scale, the scale number 0 maps to a C which is the piano key number 39. And in the C major scale, the scale number 1 maps to a D which is the piano key number 41. (Note that the C major scale skips the C# which is key number 40).

In the C blues scale, the scale number 0 is a C, which is key number 39 on the piano. But in the C blues scale the scale number 1 is an Eb, which is piano key number 42.

Author:
David Bahr

Method Detail

getCBluesChord

public static int[] getCBluesChord(long currentBeat,
                                   int octave)
For any given beat constructs an appropriate chord for the C blues.

Parameters:
currentBeat - The current beat.
octave - The octave of notes that will be returned. Possible values include TENOR, BASSO, ALTO, etc.
Returns:
An array of the pian key numbers that correspond to a chord.

getCBluesScaleOneOctave

public static int getCBluesScaleOneOctave(int scaleNumber,
                                          int octave)
For the given number of the note in the C blues scale, this returns the piano key. For the TENOR octave, this scale starts at key number 39 (middle C), and ends at key number 50 (C an octave higher). See class description for more details.

Parameters:
scaleNumber - The number of the note on the scale. Values outside 0 to 6 are reassigned to the absolute value of modulo 7 (so for example, a -1 corresponds to a 1, and a 9 corresponds to a 3).
octave - The octave of notes that will be returned. Possible values include TENOR, BASSO, ALTO, etc.
Returns:
The piano's corresponding key number.

getCBluesScaleOneOctaveLength

public static int getCBluesScaleOneOctaveLength()
The length of the blues scale (for one octave).

Returns:
The length of the one-octave blues scale.

getCMajorScaleOneOctave

public static int getCMajorScaleOneOctave(int scaleNumber,
                                          int octave)
For the given number of the note in the C major scale, this returns the piano key. This scale starts at key number 39 (middle C), and ends at key number 50 (C an octave higher). See class description for more details.

Parameters:
scaleNumber - The number of the note on the scale. Values outside 0 to 7 are reassigned to the absolute value of modulo 8 (so for example, a -1 corresponds to a 1, and a 9 corresponds to a 2).
octave - The octave of notes that will be returned. Possible values include TENOR, BASSO, ALTO, etc.
Returns:
The piano's corresponding key number.

getCPentatonicScaleOneOctave

public static int getCPentatonicScaleOneOctave(int scaleNumber,
                                               int octave)
For the given number of the note in the C pentatonic scale, this returns the piano key. This scale starts at key number 39 (middle C), and ends at key number 50 (C an octave higher). See class description for more details.

Parameters:
scaleNumber - The number of the note on the scale. Values outside 0 to 5 are reassigned to the absolute value of modulo 6 (so for example, a -1 corresponds to a 1, and an 8 corresponds to a 2).
octave - The octave of notes that will be returned. Possible values include TENOR, BASSO, ALTO, etc.
Returns:
The piano's corresponding key number.

getCModalScale

public static int getCModalScale(int scaleNumber,
                                 int numberOfNotes,
                                 int firstNote)
UNFINISHED! For the given number of the note in the scale, this returns the piano key. This scale starts at the specified note, but the scale is always in the key of C. So, for example, if the scale starts at D (but is in the key of C), then this is really the D Dorian scale. See class description for more details.

Parameters:
scaleNumber - The number of the note on the scale. Values outside 0 to 7 are reassigned to the absolute value of modulo 8 (so for example, a -1 corresponds to a 1, and a 9 corresponds to a 2).
numberOfNotes - The number of notes that are in the scale. For example, 15 covers two octaves. Must be between 1 and 88 (the number of keys on a piano).
firstNote - The first note of the scale. Must be between 0 and 87 (the number of keys on a piano). A 4039 is middle C, a 41 is middle D, etc.
Returns:
The piano's corresponding key number.
